creator: Sereng
title: Golden Era Khan

Nima’s transcription of the texts is undated. Pages from Tale Altan-ɣalab qaɣan are 590 - 894.

creator: Nimaodzer
title: How Wu Xiangbao Searched for His Father
description: Tale U Siyang Boo ecige-ben erigsen "How Wu Xiangbao Searched for His Father", 339 pp. On August 13-15, 1995 Rinčindorǰi recorded the text from the recitation of the bard Nimaodzer of Baγarin West Banner. At the end of the text, Rinčindorǰi remarks that he transcribed the text from tape without emending it, but he noticed that the text contains mistakes and narrative inconsistencies.

creator: Stefan Schnell
title: Multi-CAST Vera'a 'gaqg' ("The Seagull and the Rat")
description: Traditional narrative. Speaker VR04. Recorded in 2007 by Stefan Schnell in Vera'a village, Vanua Lava, Vanuatu. A rat is swept out to sea in its tree trunk home by heavy rains, but a helpful turtle returns it to shore. When the turtle is captured by the villagers and about to be eaten, the pigeon and the rat hatch a plan to save their friend.

creator: Stefan Schnell
title: Multi-CAST Vera'a 'hhak' ("The Devouring Devil")
description: Traditional narrative. Speaker VR05. Recorded in 2007 by Stefan Schnell in Vera'a village, Vanua Lava, Vanuatu. When a devil threatens to devour everyone, the villagers flee but leave behind a pregnant woman, saying she would sink the overcrowded canoes. The woman hides from the devil in a cave and gives birth to twins, who eventually grow into young men. When the devil returns to eat their mother, they kill it with arrows and burn its body. The smoke invites the other villagers to return.

creator: Stefan Schnell
title: Multi-CAST Vera'a 'mvbw' ("The Two Brothers")
description: Traditional narrative. Speaker VR09. Recorded in 2007 by Stefan Schnell in Vera'a village, Vanua Lava, Vanuatu. Two brothers are left to starve by their evil step-mother. When they leave in search of their late mother, her spirit hears the song they sing from Wērēsurō, the land of the dead, and comes to their aid – by having the spirits of the dead tear the step-mother to pieces.

creator: Almuth Degener
title: Nuristani Archive Cologne
description: The Nuristani Archive Cologne (NurAC) collects, preserves, and presents data from Nuristani languages, a group of related languages of the Indo-Iranian branch of Indo-European spoken mostly in eastern Afghanistan and to a lesser extent in Northern Pakistan. NurAC currently holds recordings in Waigali (Kalasha-Ala), made by Alexandr Grjunberg in the 1980s. In the near future, texts in Prasun collected by Georg Buddruss in 1956* will be available as searchable texts and translations. * cf. Buddruss, Georg, and Almuth Degener. 2015. Materialien Zur Prasun-Sprache Des Afghanischen Hindukusch. Texte Und Glossar. Harvard Oriental Series. Cambridge (Mass.): Department of South Asian Studies, Harvard University.

creator: Birgit Hellwig
title: Collection Overview
description: Our longitudinal corpus contains data on seven focal children. The PDF files give tabular overviews of the available sessions for each child (ordered according to the ID of the child: FVL, HCK, YDS, YJL, YRA, ZDL, ZJS): the child's age at each session, the name of the session, the length of the session, a description of the session, other participants, and the processing status. For an overview of the corpus structure, please visit our corpus site (https://qaqet.phil-fak.uni-koeln.de/corpus). For information on the project and the language, please visit our project site (https://qaqet.phil-fak.uni-koeln.de/).

creator: Stefan Schnell
title: Multi-CAST Vera'a 'iswm' ("The Resurrection of Wōwut")
description: Traditional narrative. Speaker VR07. Recorded in 2007 by Stefan Schnell in Vera'a village, Vanua Lava, Vanuatu. A traditional story about Wōwut and Meter, the mythical couple of Vera'a traditional oral literature. In this version, Wōwut dies and is then revived. The recording takes in the presence of the speaker's wife, who takes part in the performance by singing the traditional song within the narrative.

creator: Stefan Schnell
title: Multi-CAST Vera'a 'isam' ("Maltetrag – A Man and the Reef")
description: Traditional narrative. Speaker VR06. Recorded in 2007 by Stefan Schnell in Vera'a village, Vanua Lava, Vanuatu. A man goes fishing on the reef, but is shocked when it comes alive and moves towards the deep sea. The sentient reef takes him to the Torres Islands, northwest of Vanua Lava.

creator: Stefan Schnell
title: Multi-CAST Vera'a
description: Vera’a (ISO 639-3: vra) is an Oceanic (Austronesian) language from the village of the same name on Vanua Lava (13.80° S 167.47° E), one of the Banks Islands in North Vanuatu. The language has approximately 450 speakers and is the first language of most inhabitants of Vera’a and the coast line to the north of it. Vera’a is closely related to the neighbouring language Vurës, and speakers of Vera’a also speak Vurës. Both languages have been extensively documented within a VolkswagenStiftung-funded DoBeS documentation project (2006-2012; PI: Dr. Catriona Hyslop-Malau). Vera’a has been the focus of Stefan Schnell’s PhD project at Kiel University (2007-2010), and Stefan has subsequently been undertaking additional documentary work on Vera’a as part of his ARC-funded DECRA project “Typology of Language Use (ARC grant no. DE120102017)” in 2012-2015, hosted by La Trobe University (Melbourne, Australia). A corpus of Vera’a is being compiled and curated by Stefan Schnell in close collaboration with speakers of the language and researchers of other disciplines from outside the community. This collection of texts constitutes a sub-corpus of the Vera’a corpus and is part of Multi-CAST. It consists of 11 folkloristic narrative texts collected and annotated by Stefan Schnell. Annotations include glossing according to the GRAID conventions (Haig and Schnell 2014) which constitute the foundation of quantitative investigations into argument realisation in discourse (see also Multi-CAST: Research and publications).

creator: Issak Cheikh Oukafi
title: Interviews about Rock Art
description: The Interviews were made by Issak Oukafi Cheikh for his Master Thesis 'L'historie d'Eharir (Tassili n Azjer, Sahara) dans la perception locale de l'art rupestre'. He talked with several locals from the village Eharir in western Algeria in 2010/2011 about thier perception of ancient rock art in the region.

creator: Birgit Hellwig
title: Qaqet Child Language Corpus: Longitudinal Study
description: This corpus of the Qaqet language of Papua New Guinea was compiled as part of the project ‘Psycholinguistics and Language Documentation’ (2014-2022), generously funded by the Lichtenberg Program of the Volkswagen Foundation. Our project studies language acquisition and socialization among the Qaqet of Raunsepna and Kamanakam. Children in Raunsepna grow up with Qaqet as their dominant language (with the national language Tok Pisin playing a minor role), while children in Kamanakam grow up in a highly multilingual environment (with Tok Pisin playing a prominent role early on). The heart of the project is a longitudinal study of a number of focal children (between the ages of 2 and 4) and their older and younger siblings. Families videotaped their children, aiming for one hour each week over a period of at least one year. The goal was to record children in their typical day-to-day activities, and to thus gain an idea of their language environment and development over time. Due to the sensitive nature of child data, the data is not openly available, but it can be made available for research purposes upon request. For information, contact Birgit Hellwig (https://ifl.phil-fak.uni-koeln.de/allgemeine-sprachwissenschaft/personen/prof-dr-birgit-hellwig) and visit our archival collection site at the Data Center for the Humanities (https://dch.phil-fak.uni-koeln.de/language-data/qaqet-child-language-corpus).

creator: Birgit Hellwig
title: Zaghawa
description: This corpus of the Zaghawa-Wagi language of Sudan was compiled during the MA-level field methods course 42666 Probleme und Methodik der empirischen Sprachbeschreibung (Feldforschung) (winter term 2014/15) at the Department of Linguistics, University of Cologne. Data collection took place between October 2014 an d April 2015. This data represents an earlier, non revised version of the current, updated Beria Corpus (https://doi.org/10.18716/dch/a.00000042 , https://doi.org/10.18716/dch/a.00000043 , https://doi.org/10.18716/dch/a.00000044 , https://doi.org/10.18716/dch/a.00000045 ).

creator: Katja Hannß

creator: Damrin
title: The Story of the Golden State
description: Tale Altan ulus-un shastir “The Story of the Golden State“, 546 pp. In December 1993, Rinčindorǰi recorded the tale from the recitation of the bard Damrin of Baɣarin West Banner. On March 1995, Rinčindorǰi finished writing down the text. He also added notes to the text.

creator: Walther Heissig
title: Oral Tales of Mongolian Bards
description: The project “Oral Tales of Mongolian Bards” focuses on oral tales performed by bards of eastern Inner Mongolia, including epic poems and tales based on Chinese adventure novels, known as quγur-un üliger (huuriin üliger) “tales of the fiddle”, viz. tales accompanied by the music of the four-stringed fiddle (quγur, huur).The tales form a small portion of a larger collection of tales, oral histories of bards, and ritual songs of Qorčin (Horchin) Mongol shamans. The collection is currently preserved at the North-Rhine Westphalian Academy of Sciences and Arts in Düsseldorf. As to how the tales became a collection, in 1984, 1986, 1991, and 1995, the late Professor Walther Heissig (Bonn University), recorded part of the tales on tapes from the oral performance of bards (quγurči, huurchi, the fiddle player) in different regions of eastern Inner Mongolia. Other tales were recorded by his assistants Professor Rinčindorǰi of Baγarin (Baarin; Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, Beijing), and Mr. Nima of Jarud (Mongolian folklore specialist, Beijing). During their stays in Bonn, from 1992 to 1997, Professor Rinčindorǰi and Mr. Nima carried out the task of writing down in Mongolian the great majority of the tales in 90 large-sized notebooks. In 2010, Professor Rinčindorǰi also transcribed the two tales Modon qota / Muyang Cheng (牡羊成)-ün üliger. Mongolian: “The Story of the City of Wood“ / Chinese: “The Story of the City where Sheep are Herded“, and “The Story of the Tang Lama-priest” (Tangsuγ /Tangseng lama-yin üliger). In 2011, Professor Čoγtu (Central University for Nationalities, Beijing), provided a new transcription of Kusi ǰuwan (Kuxi zhuan)-u-nige bölög “A Chapter in the Story of Pain and Joy”. After Professor Walther Heissig died in 2005, in accordance with his wishes, the entire collection of tapes and transcriptions was donated to the North-Rhine Westphalian Academy of Sciences and Arts in Düsseldorf in 2006. The collection presented here contains digitized tape recordings and scans of the respective transcripts. Catalogue descriptions are provided by Dr. Elisabetta Chiodo (University of Bonn).

creator: Jakob Halfmann

description: These recordings were made between 28 June and 1 July 2022 in Chitral Town, Pakistan. The base of the recordings is the book "Kšulō̃ Vëri" ('Words of the Wise'), a collection of Katë proverbs with Urdu translations, compiled by Abdul Nasir Mansur under the auspices of the Pakistani NGO "Forum for Language Initiatives" (FLI). The dialect of these recordings is the Northeastern dialect of Bumboret Shekhandeh.

creator: Stefan Schnell
title: Multi-CAST Vera'a 'as1' ("The Two Friends")
description: Traditional narrative. Speaker VR02. Recorded in 2007 by Stefan Schnell in Vera'a village, Vanua Lava, Vanuatu. Two brothers looking for a particular kind of pig are deceived by the face-changing trickster Dōl.

creator: Stefan Schnell
title: Multi-CAST Vera'a 'gabg' ("The Cat and the Rat")
description: Traditional narrative. Speaker VR03. Recorded in 2007 by Stefan Schnell in Vera'a village, Vanua Lava, Vanuatu. The cat and the rat, though friends at first, part in animosity after the rat cheats the cat out of a meal of pawpaw fruit they had intended to share.

creator: Felix Rau
title: Gtaq Field Recordings
description: Gtaʔ (Diday) field recordings as gathered by Chakravarti in 1962-1964 and preserved by the Chicago Munda Language Project. The variety recorded is so called Plains Gtaʔ as spoken in Oringi village.

creator: Felix Rau
title: Chakravarti Gtaq Data 1
description: Recordings digitised on CD 1 of Chakravarti Gtaq field recordings

creator: Damrin
title: The Story of the Golden Horse
description: Tale Altan morin-u namtar “The Story of the Golden Horse“, 351 pp. Sometime in 1993, Rinčindorǰi recorded the tale from the recitation of the bard Damrin of West Baɣarin. On August 24, 1993, Rinčindorǰi finished writing down the text. On December 8, 1993, Rinčindorǰi recorded a new version of the last section of the performance, 41 pp., and finished writing down the text on January 20, 1995. Rinčindorǰi also added notes to the text.

creator: Rinčin
title: The Story of the Tang Lama-priest
description: Tale Tangsuɣ / Tangseng lama-yin üliger “The Story of the Tang Lama-priest” (i.e. Xuanzang, the Tang Monk in the summary of the text), pp. 89. On September 9, 1991 in Sili-yin qota (Shiliinhot), Walther Heissig recorded the text from the recitation of the bard Rinčin of Baɣarin (Baarin) West Banner. On October 19, 2010, Rinčindorǰi finished writing down the text.

creator: Asangba Reginald Taluah
title: Panegyric in Honour of Gundo Naa Salamatu Abdulai
description: Recording by Asangba Reginald Taluah for Ph.D Dissertation
